document.masterDocTitle: A taxonomic revision of the Solanum echinatum group (Solanaceae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A taxonomic revision of the Solanum echinatum group (Solanaceae)

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Queensland Herbarium, Brisbane Botanic Gardens, Mt Coot-tha Road, Toowong, Queensland 4066, Australia

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type :â€” AUSTRALIA . Western Australia : Cambridge Gulf , anno 1886 ,
A. Lucanus s.n.
( lectotype MEL ! [ MEL11346 ]
;
isolectotypes K , MEL !
), designated by
Symon (1981: 199)
.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Solanum longissimum Bean (2004: 795)
,
syn. nov .
Type :â€” AUSTRALIA . Queensland : Pannikan Springs area ,
29 km W of Mungana
,
26 January 1993
,
A.R. Bean 5617 & P.I. Forster
( holotype BRI!; isotype DNA!).

subSubSection.paragraph: Prostrate shrub 0.1â€“0.3 m high. Adult branchlets rusty or brown; prickles 3â€“80 per decimetre, straight, acicular, 1â€“5 mm long, 6â€“12 times longer than wide, glabrous; stellate hairs dense, 0.6â€“1.1 mm in diameter, the stalks 0â€“0.6 mm long, the central ray 1â€“1.8 times as long as laterals. Adult leaves simple, the blades ovate or broadly ovate, 3â€“8 cm long, 1.7â€“4 cm wide, 1.6â€“3.0 times longer than broad. Upper surface green or greygreen, prickles absent; stellate hairs moderate density to dense, spaced 0.25â€“0.5 mm apart, 0.6â€“0.7 mm across, the stalks 0â€“0.1 mm long, the central ray 1â€“1.8 times as long as laterals. Lower surface yellowish, prickles absent; stellate hairs moderate to dense, spaced 0.1â€“0.3 mm apart, 0.6â€“0.8 mm diameter, the stalks 0â€“0.2 mm long, the central ray 0.8â€“1.5 times as long as laterals; entire, the base cuneate or obtuse, the oblique part 0â€“5 mm long, obliqueness index 0â€“12 percent, the apex acute or obtuse; petioles 2.4â€“5.5 cm long, 55â€“115 % length of lamina, prickles absent or present. Inflorescence 3â€“4-flowered, with common peduncle 27â€“70 mm long, rachis prickles present; pedicels at anthesis 4â€“12 mm long, prickles present; calyx tube 2.5â€“3.5 mm long, the lobes deltate, 1â€“2.5 mm long; calyx prickles absent or present at anthesis, 0â€“100 per flower, 1â€“1.5 mm long; calyx stellae very dense, yellow, 0.5â€“0.9 mm across, the stalks 0â€“1.5 mm long, central ray 1â€“1.8 times as long as laterals. Corolla purple, 8â€“14 mm long, the inner surface glabrous; anthers 3.5â€“5.5 mm long; free part of the filaments 2.6â€“3.3 mm long; style 6â€“10 mm long, strongly bent near base, eccentric, glabrous. Fruiting calyx almost closed at the apex rendering fruit almost invisible; stellate hairs greatly varying in size, some with stalks exceeding 0.8 mm long, proto-prickles often present; prickles>100, 1â€“ 5 mm long, straight, glabrous or with stellae attached near their base; pedicels 15â€“30 mm long. Mature fruits 1â€“2 per inflorescence, oblate, 14â€“19 mm diameter, interior moist but not juicy, the pericarp 1.3â€“1.7 mm thick; placenta stalked, anvil-shaped. Seeds 2.3â€“2.8 mm long.

Distribution and habitat: â€”
Solanum lucani
occurs throughout tropical Australia from Cape York Peninsula, Queensland to the Kimberley region of Western Australia ( Map 3 ). It occurs in eucalypt forest or woodland, commonly on gravelly rises, laterite or sandy plains, occasionally on sandstone ranges.

caption.paragraph:
MAP 3. Distribution of
Solanum lucani
(circles);
Solanum rhaphiotes
(triangles).

subSubSection.paragraph: Phenology: â€” Flowers and fruits have been recorded for most months of the year.

Notes: â€”
Solanum lucani
is closely allied to
S. echinatum
, but differs by the longer petioles (55â€“115% of lamina length), the shorter calyx lobes ( 1â€“2.5 mm long), the longer filaments ( 2.6â€“3.3 mm long) and the fewer prickles on the branchlets (3â€“80 per decimetre).
The distributions of these species overlap extensively ( Maps 1 and 3 ), and there is evidence of some morphological intergradation between them, as some herbarium specimens are difficult to place.

This species was recently superfluously named
S. longissimum
by the present author ( Bean 2004 ). An examination of the type of
S. lucani
has established that the two names refer to the same taxon.
